poem:
Title: Morning Rife with Unrest

Coffee pours, newsprint whispers unfold,
In shadow of a silk flag, tales are told.
An exile in his own land, Omer sighs,
in the shadow of a border under foreign skies.
Cups of loneliness, filled to the brim, patrol the morning,
Dreams of home, war-torn and yawning,
Questioning peace, a painful jest,
Waking behind the world's unrest.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I can’t drink my coffee and see the Hezbollah flag’: calls for a wider war on Israel’s border Omer Shita does not want another war, but thinks Israel may need one if his family are ever going to return to their home on the country’s northern border. He has put his life on hold – living miles from his wife and children, working part-time from a laptop – so he can patrol the empty streets". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
